Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: SusChEM: New organocatalytic approaches to the stereo- and regioselective construction of acetals
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry supports the research of Professor Pavel Nagorny of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Michigan. This research project develops new chiral catalyst-controlled stereoselective transformations that proceed through highly reactive oxocarbenium ion intermediates. The chemistry of oxocarbenium ions is central to the synthesis of acetal-containing compounds such as carbohydrates and spiroketals, as well as heterocyclic compounds containing tetrahydrofuran and tetrahydropyran moieties. These functionalities are also present in numerous bioactive natural products as well as drugs and are often vital to the biological properties of these compounds. Harnessing the reactivity of oxocarbenium ions is a long-standing challenge, which is addressed utilizing chiral phosphoric acid-based catalysts to control the course of important transformations proceeding through the intermediacy of oxocarbenium ions. This project is focused on investigating catalyst-controlled stereo- and regioselective acetalization reactions. New chiral catalysts are synthesized and examined for the stereoselective/regioselective formation of spiroketals, acetals and glycosides. Structural and computational studies are performed to elucidate the mechanism of activation and the origins of selectivity. Mechanistic studies contribute to fundamental insights into catalyst structure and function, and provide opportunities for hypothesis-driven catalyst design.

Professor Nagorny's research efforts revolve around the development of new chiral phosphoric acid-based transformations involving oxocarbenium ions and application of these transformations to the synthesis of bioactive compounds and natural products. These studies will produce new techniques that will enable the discovery of new small-molecule-based therapeutic agents and improve the understanding of fundamentally important chemical and biochemical processes. In addition, these efforts will advance the field of chemical synthesis and produce new catalysts that will allow chemists to shorten synthetic sequences, saving time, money and natural resources. This research is considered sustainable as it uses phosphorus-based catalysts (organocatalysts) rather than expensive, costly and sometimes toxic transition metal-based catalysts. In addition to the technical applications of the research, this project encourages sophomore undergraduate students to consider the historical, economic, social, psychosocial, societal and legal issues associated with pharmaceuticals design and production. Students will also be carefully trained to edit Wikipedia entries in order to learn how to explain their science to a broad and diverse audience.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.The studies funded by this award have been focused on development of new types of catalytic reactions that involve selective formation of acetals using nontoxic, bench-stable and potentially recyclable organic catalysts. The chemistry of acetals is central to many medicinally important compounds and pharmaceutical agents, as many of such compounds contain acetal moieties in the form of glycosides, acetals and spiroketals. During the funding period, our group has discovered and developed new and unique chiral organocatalyst-controlled methods for installing the chiral acetal and carbohydrate-containing moieties into various organic molecules. These studies included development of new methods for the enantio- and diastereoselective formation of spiroketals, catalyst-controlled site-selective installation of acetals, and desymmetrizative glycosylation reactions (cf. Figure 1). The utility of these transformations was showcased by achieving catalyst-controlled formation of natural and unnatural aminoglycoside antibiotics by desymmetrizative glycosylation of 2-deoxystreptamine (Figure 1). This allowed to shorten the synthesis of some of these valuable antibiotics and resulted in previously unknown analogs. To explain high levels of selectivity for these transformations and to develop a stereochemical model, we conducted detailed mechanistic and computational studies of chiral catalyst-catalyzed spiroketalization reactions (Figure 1). Using modern computational methods, isotope-labeling and kinetic studies, we demonstrated that chiral phosphoric acid-based catalysts do not promote these transformations via well-established mechanisms involving oxocarbenium ion intermediates, but rather proceed through concerted transition states or covalently-linked phosphates. An important objective of this work was to improve access to common types of C2-symmetric chiral Br?nsted acids that are used as the catalysts. Thus, we developed methods for the direct interconversion of two common types of chiral catalysts (BINOL and H8-BINOL) that enabled achieving rapid access to new and existing chiral catalysts for these studies. These studies also resulted in new analytical methods allowing to achieve rapid assessment of the optical purity of chiral phosphoric acids by NMR. All of this work allowed us to design new chiral acetal-containing ligand scaffold (SPIROL) that could be used for a variety of transition metal-catalyzed reactions resulting in chiral products. These ligands demonstrate excellent performance in a variety of asymmetric transformations combined with better accessibility and lower price than some other, more established, scaffolds (Figure 1). Finally, a new undergraduate seminar course "22 ways to think about drugs" exposing undetermined sophomores to various topics related to drugs and drug discovery has been designed and successfully implemented.

The studies funded by this award (in whole or in part) have resulted in 6 peer-reviewed research publications (1 pending submission), one scientific review, one book chapter, one submitted US patent (under review), 1 M.S. thesis, 5 completed Ph.D. dissertations, and 1 Ph.D. dissertation to be defended in 2019.

Broader Impacts.  These studieshave positively impacted the society in a variety of ways. (1) The research program described in this proposal has produced new techniques that have enabled the discovery of new small molecule-based therapeutic agents and improved the understanding of fundamentally important chemical and biochemical processes involving the formation of acetals and glycosides. In addition, these efforts haveadvanced the field of chemical synthesis and produced new ligands and catalysts (that are currently being commercialized) that will allow chemists to improve the preparation of pharmaceuticals and other chiral materials. (2) The proposed studies have offered excellent opportunities for training postdoctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of asymmetric organocatalysis, organic synthesis, physical organic chemistry as well as medicinal chemistry. The training experiences enabled by this grant allowed graduate students and postdoctoral fellows (including URM students) to pursue careers in pharmaceutical industry (BMS, Merck, Eli Lilly), chemical industry (Corteva Agriscience), patent law and intellectual property (Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati) and academia as assistant professors (Indiana University Southeast, Shanghai Jiao Tong University). Three undergraduate students (including URM students) trained using this grant are pursuing postgraduate studies in chemistry at top US programs. (3) The developed and implemented course "22 ways to think about drugs" provided excellent opportunities to recruit undecided undergraduate students to STEM fields, and to educate them about the process of drug discovery, sciences associated with creating and studying drugs as well as the role drugs play in our society. In addition, these studies resulted in improving the existing public Wikipedia entries on drugs and topics related to drugs. 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/29/2019
Modified by: Pavel Nagorny

Figure 1).
